abstract.text: All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission. : medRxiv preprint 2 The coronavirus disease 2019 has resulted in high morbidity and mortality 20 worldwide since December 2019. Recent studies showed that patients with previous heart 21 disease, especially heart failure (HF), whose plasma Natriuretic Peptides (NPs) concentrations 22 are higher, were more susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection. In this study, we retrospectively 23 analyzed single-center case series of 91 patients with COVID-19 in China. 46 (50.5%) patients 24 exhibited cardiac dysfunction as indicated by elevated Natriuretic Peptides B (BNP) levels. 25 Moreover, the results indicate that patients with cardiac dysfunction had higher mortality than 26 those without cardiac dysfunction. Nonetheless, it remains unclear as to how the virus infects 27 the heart, especially in HF patients and why a higher level of BNP in the heart dampen 28 inflammation. Angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2), the critical host cellular receptor of 29 SARS-CoV-2, expresses in different organs. Still, its cellular distribution in the human heart, 30 especially in patients with HF remains unclear. Thus, we investigated ACE2 gene expression 31 pattern in single-cell RNA sequence (scRNA-seq) data of hearts from normal adults versus 32 patients with HF. Our results indicate that ACE2 is predominantly enriched in cardiomyocytes 33 (CMs), endothelial cells, fibroblasts and smooth muscle cells in normal heart. Not only ACE2+ 34 CMs, but also expression of ACE2 are significantly boosted in CMs of patients with HF. Also, 35 genes related to virus entry, virus replication and suppression of IFN-γ signaling besides ACE2 36 were up-regulated in HF patient, mainly in CMs, indicating the higher susceptibility to SARS-37

body_text.text: has spread worldwide and classified as a pandemic in 2020. As of April 2020, more than 30 51 million cases of COVID-19 and more than 200,000 deaths have been reported worldwide 2 . 52 Besides respiratory illness, the viral infection causes a series of symptoms related to myocardial 53 injury, including cardiac dysfunction 1, 3, 4 . Recent clinical studies have found that the elderly 54 and individuals with underlying comorbidities, including cardiovascular diseases such as 55 hypertension (HTN) and coronary heart disease (CAD) are more susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 56 with worse prognosis 5, 6 . Cardiac injury has also been found to be a common condition among 57 hospitalized patients with COVID-19 and is associated with a higher risk of in-hospital 58 mortality 5 . 59 Single-cell RNA sequencing has shown that the SARS-CoV-2 entry receptor, angiotensin-60 converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) is highly expressed in the nasal, kidney, endothelium, testis, and 61 heart 7-12 . Zou et al. reported that cardiomyocytes (CMs) contained ACE2 positive cells, thus 62 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 5, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.30.20081257 doi: medRxiv preprint raising the possibility of the myocardium being infected with SARS-CoV-2 9 . ACE2 functions 63 to convert angiotensin II (Ang II) into angiotensin1-7 (Ang1-7) thus preserving ejection 64 fraction in patients with HF 13 . As such, patients with underlying cardiovascular disorders such 65 as HF are more susceptible to be infected by the virus and their mortality rates are higher than 66 compared to normal patients resulting from increased ACE2 14 . Nonetheless, at the single cell 67 level, nothing much is known about the underlying mechanism as to why the failing heart is 68 more vulnerable to the virus compared with a normal heart. 69 Our present study retrospectively analyzed a single-center case series in Ezhou, China. The 70 results show that cardiac dysfunction(BNP≥100 pg/mL)in patients infected with SARS-CoV-71 2 is associated with higher mortality. We then applied single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-72 seq) to hearts from the normal adults versus patients with failing heart to elucidate the potential (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

body_text.section: CMS and Non-CMs (NCMs) shows different characteristics between normal and HF

body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 5, 2020. We further investigated ACE2+ cells frequency change of CMs and NCMs in the failing heart 257 by comparing them with normal hearts. Fig. 4A showed that the distribution of ACE2+ cells 258 during HF shifted. Additionally, we calculated the ACE2+ cells frequency across distinct cell 259 subsets of CMs and NCMs. The frequency of ACE2+ cells increased significantly in three of 260 four CMs in HF patients, especially in CM1 and CM4. The proportions rose from 5.55% to 261 31.05% (p<0.0001) and from 0% to 7.01% (p<0.0001) respectively. The frequency of ACE2+ 262 cells in CM3 significantly increased from 6.19% to 13.16% (p<0.0001), but CM2 didn't 263 change (from 5.55% to 5.66%, p>0.05) (Fig. 4B) .
body_text.section: CMS and Non-CMs (NCMs) shows different characteristics between normal and HF

body_text.text: In summary, our scRNA-seq results demonstrated that ACE2+ CMs dramatically increased 265 during HF, which suggests that HF patients are more susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 than regular 266 patients. Also, ventricular myocytes had higher percentage of ACE2+ cells than that at atrial called DEGs between these two groups. In ventricular myocytes, NPPB, the gene coding 277 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 5, 2020. (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 5, 2020. feedback loop to reserve ejection fraction in HF 20-23 patients . We further studied these ejection 289 fraction preservation genes. Interestingly, we found out that most of them not only are 290 significantly upregulated during HF, but also upregulated in ACE2+ CMs cells (Fig. 4C) . To 291 denote their relationship, we built gene regulatory network (GRN) using string (string-db.org).

GRN showed that ACE2, NPPA, NPPB, TNNT1, TNNT 2 and TNNT3 were well connected (Fig.   293 4D). Based on these co-incidence results, we speculate that these ejection fraction preservation 294 genes may affect virus infection. 295 Next, we studied the gene expression dynamics of ACE2, NPPA and NPPB in CMs and 296 NCMs during HF. Both NPPB and NPPA were co-expressed with ACE2 and significantly up-297 regulated in CMs during HF (Fig. 5A, 5B ). NPPB and NPPA have different expression pattern.

NPPA has high expression at atrial myocytes (CM2, 3) and NCMs in normal heart and was 299 significantly upregulated at all CMs (Fig. 5B) . NPPB has relatively low, but specific 300 expression at atrial myocytes (CM2, 3) in normal heart and significantly upregulated 301 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. at all CMs except CM4 (Fig. 5A) . To our surprise, NPPB is barely expressed at CM4. Then, we 308 extended our research to other virus infection-related genes, which involved in virus entry 309 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 5, 2020. (Fig. 5C-F) . Genes contributed to virus entry (Fig. 5C,5D , 312 Supplementary Fig. S2A, S2B) , virus replication (Fig. 5F ) and suppression of IFN-γ signaling 313 (Fig. 5E) were up-regulated at CMs during HF. SARS-CoV-2 entry host CMs requires ACE2 314 spike protein and protease. It was reported that SARS-CoV-2 can use ACE2 and cellular 315 protease TMPRSS2 for entry into host cells 24 . 316 317 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. during HF (Fig. 5D) . We speculate that virus mainly uses ACE2-CTSB/L axis entry into host 335 cells. The above results imply that Heart dysfunction or HF patients are more vulnerable to 336 SARS-CoV-2.
Thrombosis is the main cause accentuate illness in severe patients 26 . Tissue factor 338 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

F3 was co-340 expressed with ACE2 and significantly up-regulated in CM3 and CM1 during HF (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

Characteristics of ACE2 positive ventricular and atrial myocytes 355 We conducted GSEA analysis on DEGs of cells between ACE2+ and ACE2-in ventricular 356 myocytes (CM1 and CM4) (Fig.6A, Supplementary Fig. S3A ). GO term associated with energy 357 consumption (Fig. 6A) , energy derivation by oxidation (Fig. 6C) , and pathway influenza 358 infection ( Supplementary Fig. S3C ) and infectious disease (Fig. S3A) were positively enriched 359 in ACE2+ cells. In contrast, GO terms interferon gamma mediated signaling pathway, defense 360 response to virus and pathway interferon-alpha_beta signaling and interferon signaling were 361 negatively enriched in ACE2+ cells (Fig. 6C, Supplementary Fig. S3C ).

Furthermore, we performed GSEA analysis on DEGs of cells between ACE2+ and ACE2-363 in atrial myocytes (CM2 and CM3) (Fig. 6B, Supplementary Fig. S3B ). GO terms associated 364 with energy consumption, mitochondrial envelope, ATP synthesis coupled electron transport, 365 oxidative phosphorylation and pathway cardiac muscle contraction, respiratory electron 366 transport were positively enriched (Fig. 6B, 6C, Supplementary Fig. S3B, S3C ). On contrary, 367 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 5, 2020. GO terms and pathways associated with innate immune response, response to interferon 368 gamma, interferon gamma signaling and interferon-alpha_beta signaling were negatively 369 enriched which shared the same trend as ventricular myocytes (Fig. 6D, Supplementary Fig.   370 S3D). ACE2+ CMs are characterized with capacity of reduced immuno-regulatory effect and 371 have more energy consumption compared with ACE2-CMs. Moreover, we also identified 372 DEGs between ACE2+ NCMs and ACE2-NCMs and GSEA analysis (Supplementary Fig. S4 ). (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 5, 2020. Supplementary Fig. S4C, S4D) . Our clinical data indicates that patients with high BNP (≥100 pg/mL) were more likely to have 397 complications such as liver and kidney injury resulting in a poor prognosis. This is the first 398 study, at single-cell level, to systematically investigate ACE2 and other virus entry related 399 genes expression dynamics of CMs and NCMs in both normal heart and HF patients. In normal 400 heart, most of cell types of CMs and NCMs were detected high percentage of ACE2+ cells 401 comparing with it in the lung, which indicates heart may be infected if exposed to SARS-CoV-402 2. Chen et.al. reported that the pericytes (with marker genes ABCC9 and KCNJ8), but not the 403 cardiomyocyte were ACE2+ cells in normal hearts 28 . According to our scRNA-seq analysis, 404 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. single nucleus RNA-seq to their normal heart samples, which capture much fewer transcripts 407 than the SMART-seq using whole-cell as input. Considering the limitation of their technology, 408 our scRNA-Seq data is more comprehensive and recapitulates the real state of cells.

In the presence of cardiac dysfunction, not only the proportion of ACE2+ cardiomyocytes, to promote diuresis, natriuresis and vasodilation, which is critical for the maintenance of 424 intravascular volume homeostasis (Fig, 7B) 21 . Meanwhile, ACE2 opposes the molecular and 425 cellular effects of Ang II by converting Ang II into Ang 1-7 which acts as a vasodilator and 426 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 5, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.30.20081257 doi: medRxiv preprint 25 exerts protective effects in the cardiovascular system as well (Fig, 7B) with heart dysfunction or HF have more ACE2+ CMs and higher expression ACE2 and have 436 a higher susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infection. It was reported that SARS-CoV led to down-437 regulation of ACE2 and then up-regulate its substrates Ang II, which caused more severe lung 438 injury in mice 32, 33. Similar reaction axis was found in SARS-CoV-2 between ACE2 and Ang 439 II, and the accumulation of Ang II may further lead to vascular effectiveness in other organs 440 such as lung and kidney 34 . Moreover, BNP as an early responsive gene to stress in the 441 myocardium than ANP 35 , whose expression level was increased significantly when stimulated 442 by Ang II in human 36, 37 . In our study, DEG between ACE2+ and ACE2-ventricular myocytes 443 showed both BNP and ANP were top two genes up-regulated. We searched ENCODE database 444 for transcription factor (TF) binding sites in promoter of ACE2, ANP and BNP. Among the top 445 five TFs, they share top two TFs (AP1 and c-Jun), which imply that they are probably be co-446 regulated during HF. For Patients suffered heart dysfunction and secreting ineffective NPs, if 447 their hearts are infected by SARS-CoV-2, they don't have enough effective NPs and Ang1-7 448 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

FIGREF0.text: novel disease termed Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) caused by severe acute 49 respiratory syndrome, coronavirus 2(SARS-CoV-2) broke out in December 2019 1 . The virus50

FIGREF1.text: 73 mechanisms of acute myocardial injury caused by SARS-CoV-2 infection. ACE2 transcript 74 was detected in all types of cells in heart, including cardiomyocytes (CMs), endothelial, 75 fibroblasts and smooth muscle cells and immune cells. A type of abnormal CMs (CM4) was 76 identified specifically in HF patients. Genes related to virus entry, virus replication and 77 suppression of IFN-γ signaling besides ACE2 were up-regulated in HF patient. Interestingly, 78 ACE2-postive (ACE2+) ventricular myocytes expressed high NPs. We demonstrated that the 79 increased expression of ACE2, BNP and ANP during heart failure predisposes to SARS-CoV-80 2 infection. ACE2, BNP and ANP therefore could be a novel therapeutic target to prevent the 81 SARS-CoV-2 infection.

FIGREF3.text: heart scRNA-seq datasets were obtained from Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) 121 under accession codes GSE109816 and GSE121893. Shortly, samples from fourteen healthy 122 donors, six HF patients who were undergoing heart transplantation and two patients with heart 123 failure before and after LV assist device (LVAD) treatment were obtained. The range of donor 124 ages was 21-52 year, with a median age of 45.5 year.

FIGREF5.text: 132 from the mitochondrial genome were discarded. For the remaining cells, gene expression 133 matrices were normalized to total cellular read count using negative binomial regression 134 method implemented in Seurat SCTransform function. Cell-cycle scores were calculated using 135 Seurat CellCycleScoring function. The Seurat RunPCA functions were performed to calculate 136 principal components (PCs). We further corrected the batch effect using Harmony because 137 batch effects among the human heart samples were observed. The RunUMAP function with 138 default setting was applied to visualize the first 35 Harmony aligned coordinates. The 139 FindClusters function with resolution=0.2 parameter was carried out to cluster cells into 140 different groups. Canonical marker genes were applied to annotate cell clusters into known 141 biological cell types. Monocle 3 16 as used to perform trajectory and pseudotime analysis.

FIGREF6.text: Identification of differential expression genes (DEG)143    To identify DEG between two groups, we applied the Seurat FindMarkers function with the 144 default parameter of method "MAST" and cells ID from each defined group (e.g. ACE2+ cells 145 vs ACE2-cells in CM1) as input.

FIGREF8.text: 160 lymphocyte (0.50 [0.27, 0.78] 10^9/L) was significantly lower. Generally, organ impairment 161 was significantly more severe in higher BNP group, including worse liver function indicated 162 by aspartate transaminase (AST, 41.5 [29.0, 64.0], U/L), direct bilirubin (6.6 [4.0, 13.2], 163 μmol/L), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH, 407.0 [288.0, 599.0], U/L) and worse renal function 164 indicated by eGFR (86.5±44.5, mL/(min*1.73m2) and blood urea nitrogen (BUN, 9.0 [5.2, 165 15.9], mmol/L). Cardiac injury indicated by troponin I (0.05 [0.03, 0.25], ng/mL) was 166 significant in higher BNP group. Electrolytes disturbance with elevated potassium (4.19 [3.64, 167 4.70], mmol/L) and decreased calcium (1.97±0.18, mmol/L) level were observed in higher 168 BNP group. Among the coagulation profiles, prothrombin time (PT, 13.9 [12.8, 16.7], s) was 169 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF9.text: 177 had a higher incidence of respiratory failure (RF, 31.43%, p=0.0064) (Fig. 1A). BNP level was 178 positively correlated with procalcitonin (r=0.6365, p<0.0001, R2=0.38), neutrophil (r=0.5263, 179 p<0.0001, R2=0.25), and D-dimer (r=0.5824, p<0.0001, R2=0.33), but negatively correlated 180with lymphocyte (r=-0.5585, p<0.0001, R2=0.29).(Fig. 1B-E). Of note, mortality was 181 significantly increased through a 30-day follow-up in the higher BNP group. (Log-rank 182 p<0.0001)(Fig. 1F).

FIGREF10.text: 185 study was performed according to the description of Wang et al 18 . Shortly, the samples of 186 fourteen healthy donors (hereinafter called normal) were obtained. Six HF patients were 187 undergoing heart transplantation and two patients with HF before and after left ventricle 188 assist device (LVAD) treatment (hereinafter called patient). 9767 out of 9994 cells from 189 normal and 4931 out of 4933 cells from patient passed standard quality control and retained 190 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF12.text: Relationships between BNP level and clinical assessments.192 A，the bars were constituted by percentages of non-respiratory failure (RF), type 1 RF, and 193 type 2 RF patients. There were 79.17% patients with non-RF, 20.83% RF1, and no RF2 in 194 BNP<100 pg/mL group, while 68.57% non-RF, 8.57% RF1, and 22.86% RF2 in BNP≥100 195 pg/mL group. The proportion of groups was significantly different (p=0.0064). B, C, D and 196 E ， the procalcitonin, neutrophil, and D-dimer level presented a significantly positive 197 correlation with BNP level after log transformation, and lymphocyte presented a negative 198 correlation. F，K-M estimate showed the mortality in BNP≥100 pg/mL (dash line) group 199 (58.7%) was significantly higher compared with BNP<100 pg/mL (solid line) group (11.11%) 200 after a 30-day follow-up. 201 for subsequent analyses. On average, we detected 1649 and 1904 genes in individual cell from 202 normal and patient, respectively. Then, we performed uniform manifold approximation and 203 projection (UMAP) and clustering analysis and grouped the entire population into nine clusters 204 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF13.text: UMAP for an individual sample was separately plotted side by side and exhibited the 210 differential distribution of subsets between normal and HF patients. As shown inFig. 2C, all 211 nine subsets were detected in both normal and patient group. However, different cell type 212 displayed various cell number percentage change between normal and patients. CM1 213 percentage dramatically decreased from 39.65% to 7.12% (p<0.0001), while the percentage of 214 CM4 significantly increased from 0.03% to 7.81% (p<0.0001). CM2 and CM3 also increased 215 from 17.70% to 20.08%(p<0.0001) and 8.27% to 11.56%(p=0.0005)respectively.216Cell numbers of endothelial and fibroblasts were also increased from 16.79% to 217 24.07%(p<0.0001) and 4.53% to 10.97% (p=0.0018) after HF, respectively(Fig. 2D). Their 218 cell percentage changes during HF suggest different cell type has a specific response, especially 219 in cardiomyocytes, endothelial cells and fibroblasts. For each cluster, we calculated the cluster-220 specific expression genes (marker genes). Left ventricle (LV) marker genes MYL2 and MYL3 221 were highly expressed in CM1 and 4; so, we termed the subsets CM1 and 4 as LV 222 cardiomyocytes. Left atrium (LA) marker genes MYH6 and MYH7 are highly expressed in 223 CM2 and 3, they were termed as LA cardiomyocytes 19 .

FIGREF15.text: Integrated analysis of normal and HF conditions at single-cell resolution 226 A, UMAP clustering of 14698 cells isolated from normal and heart failure patients. Each dot 227 represents a single cell. Cell type was annotated by the expression of known marker genes. B, 228 Dot plotting showing gene signature among different clusters, the shadings denotes average 229 expression levels and the sizes of dots denote fractional expression. C, Split views show the 9 230 subsets in normal and patient group. D, The percentage of cell number for different cell types 231 in normal and patient group.

FIGREF17.text: and NCMs have high percentage of ACE2+ cells. These results suggested that 237 all kind of cell type in heart are liable to SARS-CoV-2. In addition, for atrial monocytes of 238 failing heart, GO results showed us that genes related to mitochondrial protein complex and 239 other related to ATP synthesis are up-regulated while genes related to inflammatory response, 240 leukocyte migration, response to interferon-gamma and others related to defend against 241 pathogens are downregulated, indicating failing atrial monocytes is characterized with lower 242 resistance to virus (Supplementary Fig. S1A). From these results, CMs show different 243 characteristics from normal and failing heart, indicating different role in virus infection. 244 To further determine the relationship between CM1 and CM4, we performed trajectories 245 analysis of the integrated clusters to show the pseudotime of CMs and NCMs. Trajectory and 246pseudotime results indicated CM4 originated from CM1(Fig. 3A), which is consistent with 247 our speculation that CM4 is a type of abnormal CM after HF. Then we conducted GSEA248 analysis (GO and Pathway) on DEG between CM4 and CM1. GO term viral gene expression 249 and pathway influenza infection, infectious diseases and HIV infection were upregulated in 250 CM4 (Fig. 3B and C); but GO term response to virus, defense response to virus, response to 251 interferon gamma and innate immune response, and pathway the adaptive immune response, 252

FIGREF18.text: CMs and NCMs have different ACE2 expression pattern256 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF19.text: 267 myocytes, which indicate that they have different response to SARS-CoV-2. ACE2+ cells 268 percentage in NCMs showed a various pattern, for example, the percentage of ACE2+ cells in 269 fibroblasts(p<0.0001)and smooth muscle cells (p=0.0104) were decreased. The frequency 270 of ACE2+ cells in immune subsets NK-T Cell/Monocytes and granulocytes increased from 271 3.77% to 4.85%(p>0.05), 2.04% to 5.83%(p> 0.05), respectively. 272 Virus infection-related genes are upregulated in HF patients compared with normal 273 First, we focused on gene expression dynamics of SARS-CoV-2 entry receptor, ACE2. GO term associated with 390 viral expression is positively enriched in ACE2+ granulocytes, while GO term associated with 391 immunocyte mediated immunity is negatively enriched in ACE2+ granulocytes and ACE2+ 392 NK-T Cells/Monocytes which indicates their dysfunctions to fight against pantheons 393 (

FIGREF32.text: 410 especially ventricular myocytes, was dramatically increased in HF patients, but also the 411 expression level of ACE2+ cells are significantly enhanced in cardiomyocytes, especially the 412 ventricular myocytes as well (Fig. 4B). In our study, we have done two kinds of comparison 413 for each type of CMs: 1) DEGs between failing CMs and normal cells, 2) DEG between ACE2+ 414 CMs with ACE-CMs. Interestingly, following GSEA analysis ( GO and pathway) of DEGs 415 for these two kinds of comparisons achieved consistent results, in which GO term/Pathway 416 associated with virus infection and virus genes expression were positively enriched, but defense 417 to virus, secretion of IFN and activation of immune system were negatively enriched in CMs 418 (Fig. 3B,3C, 6A, 6B). Our results suggest that patients with heart dysfunction or HF may have 419 a higher susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infection (Fig. 7A). 420 The natriuretic peptide system (NPS), including ANP and BNP play an important role in 421 chronic heart failure by synergizing with the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) 422 and sympathetic nervous system (SNS) 29 . In the early stage of heart failure, NPs are released423

FIGREF33.text: progresses, the release of functional and effective NPs is blocked, exhibited 428 increasing NPs but ineffective levels in plasma, further result in the heart dysfunction 30 . 429 Previous studies have established that failed CMs could secrete poorly active prohormones like 430 pro-ANP and pro-BNP 31 . COVID-19 patients SARS-CoV-2 infection could cause a series of 431 symptoms related to myocardial injury, including cardiac dysfunction. So, we speculate NPs 432 may play an important role in virus infection and following heart injury. 433 Patients suffered heart dysfunction and secreting ineffective NPs including pro-ANP and 434 pro-BNP may have different scenario. Our scRNA-seq analysis results indicate that patients 435

FIGREF34.text: ACE2, ineffective NP, virus and Ang II formed a positive feedback loop, which lead 451 to severe outcome. In summary, there have two scenarios for COVID-19 patients with heart 452 dysfunction: 1) For patients have normal level of effective NPs, they may benefit from 453 protective effects of NPs and ACE2 negative feedback loop and have better prognosis (Fig. 454 7B). 2) For patients have deficient level of effective NPs, a positive feedback loop may be 455 formed with ACE2, ineffective NP, virus, which cause worse prognosis (Fig. 7C). Drug ACEI 456 or ARBs can break this positive feedback loop by reducing Ang II. They maybe benefit from 457 these kinds of drugs, including ACEI, ARBs and LCZ696/Entresto. Ratio of effective versus 458ineffective NPs may be the very important factor to make decision whether patients can take 459 these drugs or not.

TABREF0.text: Patients admitted to Ezhou Central Hospital, Ezhou, China with laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 were included in this retrospective cohort study, which was conducted from January 25, 2020, to March 15, 2020. The patients with COVID-19 enrolled in this study were diagnosed according to World Health Organization interim guidance 15 . The cases without a BNP measurement were excluded. This study was approved by the National Health Commission of China and Shanghai Tenth People's Hospital, Tongji University School of Medicine (Shanghai, China). Written informed consent was waived by the ethics committee of the designated hospital for patients with emerging infectious diseases.Data CollectionThe demographic characteristics, clinical data (comorbidities, laboratory findings, and outcomes), laboratory findings for participants during hospitalization were collected from electronic medical records. Cardiac biomarkers measured on admission were collected, including TNI, CK-MB, and BNP. All data were independently reviewed and entered the computer database by three analysts. Patients were categorized according to the BNP. Acute heart failure (HF) was defined as blood levels of BNP above 100 pg/ml, regardless of cardiovascular disease history and new abnormalities in electrocardiography and 100 echocardiography. The clinical outcomes (i.e., discharges and mortality) were monitored up to March 15, 2020.PCR-Fluorescence probing based kit ( Novel Coronavirus(2019-nCoV) Nucleic Acid Diagnostic Kit, Sansure Biotech, China) was used to extract nucleic acids from clinical sample All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

TABREF1.text: and detect the ORF1ab gene (nCovORF1ab) and the N gene (nCoV-NP) according to the manufacturer's instructions. An infection was considered laboratory-confirmed if the 106 nCovORF1ab and nCoV-NP tests both showed positive results.Statistical AnalysisDescriptive statistics were obtained for all study variables. Continuous data were expressed asmean (SD) or median (interquartile range [IQR]) values. Categorical data were expressed as proportions. All continuous variables were compared using the t-test or the Mann-Whitney Utest if appropriate. In contrast, categorical variables were analyzed for the study outcome by Fisher exact test or χ2 test. The Pearson correlation coefficient and Spearman rank correlation 113 coefficient were used for liner correlation analysis. Survival analysis between patients with BNP<100 pg/mL and ≥100 pg/mL was conducted by the Kaplan-Meier estimate with p-value 115 generated by the log-rank test. Data were analyzed using SPSS version 25.0 (IBM Corp) or Graphpad Prism 8.0.1 (GraphPad Software, San Diego, CA). For all the statistical analyses, 2sided p<0.05 was considered significant.

TABREF2.text: GSEA (Version 4.03) was used to perform gene ontology (GO) term and pathway enrichment analysis with the Molecular Signatures Database (MSigDB, C2 and C5, Version 7.01).ANP and BNP plasma concentrations, which correlates with cardiovascular disease severity.BNP is widely recognized as a diagnostic marker and therapeutic hormone in clinical practice17 . Patients with higher BNP were older (median age, 79 [44-89] years vs. 62 [27-79] years; p<0.0001). In the higher BNP group, levels of white blood cell (13.05 [6.76, 18.13] 10^9/L)

TABREF3.text: prolonged and D-dimer (6.96 [3.25, 24.2], μg/mL) level was significantly raised. Inflammatory biomarkers, as procalcitonin (1.01 [0.39, 3.51], ng/mL) and hsCRP (18.00 [13.45, 21.50], mg/L), showed a more intense infection in higher BNP group. Blood gas analysis was comparable between groups. Noteworthy, mortality (58.70%) was significantly higher in
